title: If This Reddit Style Goes Live, I'm Done
body:
I don't use Reddit because I find the style unreadable, illogical, and user unfriendly. Rather than having conversations that occur in chronological order like discussions SHOULD happen, you have discussions that become sprawling messes that bloat out other discussions. It becomes drastically more difficult to follow conversations unless they happen to be the most popular conversation in the topic.

I stayed on the LoL forums because I enjoy the community here, and because I enjoy forum interactions overall - even after I've mostly stopped playing.

There is no variation of this upvote centric nested topic style that I will like, so I guess my time being a part of this fine community is limited.

Thank you Riot for creating a good community - but no thanks for thinking Reddit's popularity comes from it's format being usable. There's a reason every other site that has tried to use it has failed shortly after... Reddit's success lies in when it came about and the communities that have built within it, not in it's format.

Edited on August 30 2014: I didn't realize this thread would remain popular enough to get views a year after I created it, so I want to point out that when I made this thread 'chronological view' wasn't an option since nearly every comment in the past while has been about it ;)

replies.body:
I appreciate your perspective, and would like to get to the root of why conversations are hard to follow, and why you feel like direct replies are a "sprawling mess".

I would however, like to challenge the idea that conversations occur in chronological order, particularly when more than one person is involved. A discussion is often a topic which spurs further conversations from different people who chose to react at different times, and also only choose to react to either the original post, or a response to that post. 

In a typical chronological format, one would have to read every single reply to determine which ones were directed at you, or which ones were directed at which response you made. Quotes can only get you so far when trying to carry a decent conversation. One of our goals is to make effective use of your time, and nested replies allow for that kind of conversation to be more easily facilitated and followed.

A fair point, and it is valid. But there are a few things that make it extremely awkward. 

First and foremost... unless the thread you're following is either the most recent one started or the most popular it's impossible to view it in any reasonable way. In a traditional forum you just have to remember what page you were last at and you can instantly jump to it. In a reddit you have to either go to your profile(assuming you actually posted in it and are not just following it without posting) or you have to scroll and hope it's still in the same place as it was before. And if a different thread has come up that has a lot of likes, that thread is displaced and you end up reading every thread anyways in the hopes of finding the one you were following.

Secondly... having posts and comments constantly changing positions leads to a TON of re-reading. This leads to a ton of wasted time. Time that leads to me being less able to follow discussions.

Thirdly... as someone who, when he follows a thread, FOLLOWS the thread, this type of format makes that extremely difficult. I don't care what other people think is the most popular post... I want to read everyone's opinions. With a traditional forum, I'll remember which page I've read up to... and just read from there. With a reddit style, no matter how I sort it, I have to re-read basically every post since even if you sort it by 'most recent' it only sorts it by when the subconversation started as opposed to being able to just straight up read from where I last left off.

Fourthly... As someone who likes to be involved in the conversation on the whole... a forum allows me to reply to multiple people at once. Meaning I only need to make one post. Since most forums have post limitations, this is important. It sucks seeing 3-4 things you want to reply to, and in stead of being able to just do one big reply quoting people respectively... you have to make one short post, wait x minutes, make another short post, wait x minutes, etc. 

There are more reasons why I hate the format... but it's almost 1 AM and my mind is starting to lag.
As some one that dosent really like to reply to much, I rather enjoy an up vote type system. Seeing relative information, that has popular opinion really helps me as a reader.

I think that upvote/downvote are a good addition to a community site, but I think if a traditional forum style had a 'view only popular posts' option, it might allow for what you're looking for without a complete redesign like this.
Very constructive feedback. Thank you for taking the time to explain out specific experiences, it really helps!
Also, Reddit sucks without Reddit Enhancement Suite app.
This is exactly how I feel. Well written.

Here are two kinda threads that have a comparable topic. I'm wondering if - reading through both of these you could highlight some more specific examples of where this model breaks down versus traditional boards.

Like, in TOTAL do you come away with a better understanding of diverse perspectives in the flat versus the threaded approach? Do you feel as though there are important points that won't get visibility, if so which ones, etc?

http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/c/ideas/1u0Pnp0A-gender-in-league

http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=2646142&page=1

Really appreciate your time and thinking.

I believe I now understand where our disagreements lie. I'm not making the problems I have clear...

It isn't about the first time you read a thread. Both of them work about the same from that perspective. It's about participating in a thread, FINDING topics of discussion, getting your topic noticed, and following threads.

Participating in threads is more difficult since you can only reply to one point at a time, and you have to create tons of separate posts that artificially clutter the thread and also force you to run into the post timer issue far more frequently.

Finding discussions is far more difficult since you are only exposed to the most popular topics unless you explicitly choose to view new threads in which case ALL you see are new threads. This one or the other approach imposes unfriendly restrictions and makes me make a decision I don't feel I should have to make. Forums let me view both new and popular content, why can't this community site do the same?

Getting a new topic noticed is probably the biggest issue with the reddit style. This relates to the last post. If people are forced to choose between seeing either new or popular topics, the vast majority of the time they're going to choose popular. Not because they're NOT interested in new topics, but because it's just too much work to keep track of both. Since they KNOW they're interested in whatever popular topics they're following, why bother wasting their time looking elsewhere?
Because so many people will quite likely make that decision, the number of people who even get the CHANCE to know your thread exists is drastically reduced, and thus the chance of your thread getting any meaningful discussion is drastically reduced - even if your thread is insightful and interesting.

The problems with following threads lie in the fact that there's no way to know 'where you left off'. If I'm following a forum thread, and when I leave for work they're at page 12 all I need to do is remember that I was at page 12. When I get home, I start at page 12 and read however many new posts there are. In the Reddit style, I have to basically reread the ENTIRE discussion because even if I choose 'recent' it will just show me the recent threads, not recent replies to old threads. This means if I want to truly follow a thread, I have to literally read over the entire thing again to look for new posts in each and every thread that exists within the discussion. And since there are no pages, that means I could potentially have an IE window that is so long it starts to lag.

Once again, it isn't about the first time you read a thread. It's about everything else. The first time you read a thread is largely the same - and possibly slightly better in this format. Everything else, however, is problematic.

> Participating in threads is more difficult since you can only reply to one point at a time, and you have to create tons of separate posts that artificially clutter the thread and also force you to run into the post timer issue far more frequently.

Sure – but the plus side is that it’s a LOT easier to see who has replied to you because every post is a reply to some other post. I see that as a tradeoff

> Getting a new topic noticed is probably the biggest issue with the reddit style. This relates to the last post. If people are forced to choose between seeing either new or popular topics, the vast majority of the time they're going to choose popular. Not because they're NOT interested in new topics, but because it's just too much work to keep track of both. Since they KNOW they're interested in whatever popular topics they're following, why bother wasting their time looking elsewhere? Because so many people will quite likely make that decision, the number of people who even get the CHANCE to know your thread exists is drastically reduced, and thus the chance of your thread getting any meaningful discussion is drastically reduced - even if your thread is insightful and interesting.

I posted here http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/c/beta-feedback/OI8QmnuW-if-this-reddit-style-goes-live-im-done?comment=0005000000000001000000000000 - but I'm actually not sure this problem exists any more than it does on the flat/bumping model. We'll definitely be doing a deep analysis to see if that's the case though.


> Finding discussions is far more difficult since you are only exposed to the most popular topics unless you explicitly choose to view new threads in which case ALL you see are new threads. This one or the other approach imposes unfriendly restrictions and makes me make a decision I don't feel I should have to make. Forums let me view both new and popular content, why can't this community site do the same?

You’re only exposed to a limited set of topics in either case. If you think about the recent/bump model in the case of general discussion you’re exposed to things that have a reply in the last 5 minutes or so. In this model you’re exposed to discussions that have a lot of traction. All I’m asserting is that
Since you’re only going to see a limited number of discussions, and a limited number of posts within every discussion that we want those discussions to be the MOST relevant to you.



>The problems with following threads lie in the fact that there's no way to know 'where you left off'. 

Totally 100% agree! This is just the start not the end. I'm hoping that we'll be able to make leaps and bounds improvements on this. As a team we have the goal of you being able to see what's changed and it's not something that's done well right now.

As far as the exposure goes, I don't agree. In a forum, you have a brief window of exposure to EVERYONE. In the reddit style, you have just as brief a window(as let's face it, tons of new topics are created every few minutes), except you aren't exposed to everyone. You're only exposed to the very small number who are ACTIVELY SEEKING new topics at that exact moment.

Essentially in stead of having a brief window where everyone on the forum could potentially have their eye alight on your forum subject and be interested... you only have a very small number of people - and these people would have seen it anyways.

As to the 'giving people choice'... they already have choice: They can click in your thread, or they can ignore it. If they were forced to read your thread regardless, then you might have a point about that... but I see threads I'm not interested in all the time... does it negatively affect my experience? No. I just scroll down to the next on the list. Oddly, these threads that don't interest me? Usually the most popular threads.

You say "Most relevant to you" - I find that kind of offensive. The system doesn't have any special algorithm to determine interest to a specific person. It merely tracks three things: public opinion, current activity, and how recent a thread was posted. None of those have ANY bearing in how relevant a topic is to me. The reality of it is this system assumes everyone's the same, and if you're not it gives you the finger.
Edit: And I think that last paragraph has just by complete accident nailed down my biggest problem with the approach you're taking...

Just as a final note... following this thread, thanks to the pain of the format, is becoming a 10+ minute affair just to follow this one topic... I just don't have the time to invest for that for ONE topic. If you wish to discuss any feedback further with me I'd be more than happy to, you can reach me at my website e-mail address Sean(at)shadowedblade.net

I also wanted to say that I appreciate the fact that you guys are at least reading feedback and performing quick iteration based off the feedback - no matter how much I hate this format, I still respect that you guys have the best communication with your fans in the business and that, outside of a few cases where it almost seems as though tunnelvision overrides this, for the most part you guys seem to genuinely care what the fans think and you guys have used that to build what is generally a great community, despite the negative impression people sometimes give it.

That doesn't change the fact that this format is intolerable for me, but I still wanted to state it before I stopped posting here. Hopefully the feedback from this thread from myself and others can be used to steer you guys in a direction that won't drive me away, but for the moment I just can't take this format any longer.

Thank you, and the other reds in the thread, for taking the time to actually take this criticism seriously.

I've made a quick video going over the topic you've provided.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NLC9b6a8pcg

I'm not a great speaker but hopefully I went over everything clear enough. I figured it'd be better if you saw exactly what it was I think most people don't like.

Copying this over from the video description because I did ramble a bit:
My main points were these:  

1. The first most popular opinions always reach the top. This is good for showing immediate information to new readers, but bad for following a conversation and watching it unfold.  
2. Best posts are sorted by a popularity contest, unpopular opinions do not see the light of day.  
3. (Important) Child comments on popular comments are almost completely irrelevant and painfully detract from the readability and continuity of the thread.  
4. Those little icons glitch up and refuse to go away sometimes.  
5. It's hard to tell where child comments end and top-level comments begin.

Hey Climax,

First off, I'd like to say I really appreciate the time and energy you took to record your use of the system and your thoughts. This sort of review, to see someone using the system and talking about it, is extremely helpful to us.

Could I ask you a huge favor and do the same kind of video review on the above topic Pendragon posted from the vBulletin forums? I know it's asking a lot, but it would useful to see how you navigate the conversation in the old format.

Thanks!

I had to redo this video about three times so I sound a tad winded.

http://youtu.be/a68SVfh2yQE (Video finished processing, available in 1080p)

The short version of what I go over:

**+1 Reddit** for better ability to view Riot posts.  
**+1 Reddit** for more variety in styling. Being able to break bigger posts up and insert headers would make larger threads more readable.  
**+1 vBulletin** for bbcode. Probably biased because of experience with bbcode and experience with markup languages, but I prefer [bracket tags]. I also hate the space-space-enter with a passion (just in case nobody picked up on that, lol).  

After that it gets really hard to assign point values to stuff because everything becomes a trade-off as opposed to just better or worse than the other.

Yes, Reddit does a better job at sorting posts by their value, but as a result it becomes more difficult to follow a thread over time.

Also, because threads are no longer threaded, it becomes impossible to respond to multiple posts at once. Quoting people is no longer as straight forward and quotes aren't as specific to their source as in vBulletin.

There's also a huge damage to the sense of community because vBulletin threads are much more conductive to conversation and human speech flow than Reddit style posts, which seem to be more a barrage of information fighting for the top positions.

I also have to take points off for Riot's community boards overall, because there is a sense of indignation that comes with having no avatar, no signature, and no distinguishing values to your profile. I understand not wanting too much clutter and getting rid of forum attention whores, but both vBulletin and the Reddit feel more like a 4chan/kusaba style anonymous board than they do a community.

Just my two cents.

Was very cool to see your in-depth examination of the two styles. Thanks so much for sharing these! Some good things to talk about.

*(and hey, you pronounced my name right!)*

I think it would be really helpful for us if you could show some examples of threads on the forums that you REALLY enjoyed following on the old forums. 

A big part of the threaded/sort by best model is that we should be able to preserve the same flow of conversation while improving the signal to noise ratio. I'd love to see if we could translate one of those conversations into this model and see if it's just as easy to follow.

Then as far as following a single discussion over a longer period of time - I agree that the model needs work. My hope is that we're going to find a really elegant way to show you what's changed since the last time you visited a thread, and an easy way to traverse through the discussion tree to follow the changes.

I agree with Sproctor on this (though I'm clicking reply on Pendragon for visibility). Champion rework discussions are the most obvious example - which does not make them the ONLY example, mind, just the easiest one to explain.

In a discussion, the flow of discussion generally changes over time, and this is what makes champion rework threads such a great example. The conversation will start at point A - "Hey guys. We're looking to rework this champion. Here are some details, give me your thoughts." Then everyone chips in with their thoughts, discuss different possibilities, what have you. Then the designer comes back and gives his feedback, responds to a couple of people, etc. While this "phase" of the conversation happens, a reddit style is probably just fine. However, in these rework threads, there is inevitably some bigger, more important red post that changes the flow or direction of discussion - if you look at the Skarner rework, this happens several times. The idea comes up to move the shield's secondary components off onto the E and the Q, and in the traditional forum style, the flow of conversation then changes. As far as discussion goes, posts from before this revelation are less relevant, and it's assumed that posts after this point are accounting for this change. In the old forums, the discussion has now evolved. However, in this reddit style... how does one even denote that the flow of conversation has changed? One red post doesn't work, because only people reading/responding to that specific post will know about it. It's also unclear how that post has affected other branches of discussion, if it's done so at all. The alternative is to add it to the original post as an edit, which is kind of fine for new branches, but it's unclear which branches were made after that edit; which ones are taking that into consideration and which aren't. It makes discussion foggy, and results in a lot of tangent branches that trail incredibly far off from the current focus of discussion. Now imagine there are five more iterations of this, each one massively changing the intended focus of discussion as the rework progresses.

The strength of the old discussion style is that the discussion is always laser-focused. Everyone is on the same page with the discussion, or at least not too far off - by the nature of that style of discussion, tangents die off, and the posters that contributed to them return to the main branch of conversation. In this example, every time a new "big" red post comes in, the discussion shifts - it's assumed that new posts take that change into consideration, and it's VERY CLEAR to the reader which posts come before and after those shifts. It results in a single thread of discussion, even if that single thread changes direction here or there.

The reddit style, on the other hand, results in a broad web of discussions spawned off the same topic (assuming posters care enough to keep clicking "show more" on the threads of that web). That's kind of fine for those taking part in the discussion in those threads (which eventually turn into tangents), but it's much harder for someone to jump in and find the flow of conversation, and harder to identify which post comes from which shift in flow. I think it's fine for short-lived discussion, but any long-form discussion gets diffused by this style.

(I would just like to reiterate that while this is ESPECIALLY true for champion rework discussions, it is NOT the only case where this applies. Every long-term discussion evolves over time - it's just slightly less noticeable than the instant shifts followed by red posts.)

Edit: I also dislike the comment about the "signal to noise" ratio. Aside from the most extreme (ie, bannable) cases, I abhor the idea of letting popular opinion decide what I would consider "noise." How is anything aside from popular opinion supposed to be discovered in that environment? Blegh.

Edit edit: It's also impossible for this format to "preserve the same flow of conversation" when the presentation is entirely different.

"I agree with Sproctor on this (though I'm clicking reply on Pendragon for visibility)."

This is a great example of one of the BAD things about the Reddit style "discussions".  You can game it.

Someone mentioned champ discussions, and I think in line with that are the other efforts of players that sometimes lasted MONTHS.  Lux, Lee sin, Bunny riven, Colorblind mode, etc.  The corresponding reddit thread would last a day at most, while the community would bump the GD post nonstop.  And it wasn't just a few either, there were thousands of players in on it.

There's only a handful of threads that I know of that have that kind of traction EVER on reddit.  One of those was Chausters AMA, where he would just always post answers whenever he had time in between queues.  So while big efforts to keep something alive sometime exist on reddit, I think that reddit encourages the easily consumed and forgotten model of news.  

Another thing is that the reddit format replaces the community games of bumping threads(mods asleep post ponies, count to x number, go through abc's without a red posting, etc.) with circlejerks and pun replies.  I think there is an inherit difference with these.  One is a regularly occurring thing that pops up when the forum is going slow and people want to just chat casually, while the upvote/downvote system very rarely lets these things through.  This doesn't get rid of this energy though, it just goes through another outlet...which can be quite inferior at times.

Not that I'm against this rework at all, but just listing a couple of opposing view.  I'm a pretty avid reddit user myself.

I like following the champion rework discussions. I'll scan through until I get to a red post that I don't remember reading and read from there.

Being able to toggle the view to a chronological view or new posts view (with links or expandable context containing the parent posts).

I do really like this format in general though.

One thing not mentioned, with a voting system. The bandwagon effect becomes a MAJOR issue, even reddit released a recent update that allows for sub-reddits to control when scores for a comment will show up so people don't mass up vote or down vote.

Also, there is going to be a further loss of quality, as easier to consume items are going to be faster upvoted to the top. Namely some champion specific discussion may be buried if not enough people play them, while memes and other easier to consume, less serious posts will have a easier time to float to the top.

It can be solved by heavy moderation, much like how askscience or askhistorians has done, but that may be out of reach of riot as it means full time moderators for a possibly small pool of players.
This is part of the reasoning behind to giving memes & games their own sub-community. That and the fact that some users (myself for example) tend to enjoy light, easy to digest content.

Well, this is suited towards light hearted banter. It's reddits strong point.

Actual discussion gets butchered by this format. I know vbulletin allows for notifications, and I know vbulletin allows for following a post to easily find it again. I know vbulletin allows you to find your own posts/threads, and I know vbulletin allows for tagging and changing votes. Heck, it even allows for hiding vote tally to the degree you want.

Can you please provide a reason why we are being forced into reddit? What about it do you feel is superior to vbulletin, in a serious discussion sense. After all, that is what is getting replaced here.

There are tons of ways we can reduce the bandwagon effect and you've hit on one.  Some examples are

- Adjusting the display algorithms (best scales, hardest to do)
- Moderation (Easiest to do, hardest to scale)
- General culture/standards setting (small tweaks to encourage people to treat high-investment content better than LIC)
- Adding friction to LIC (not having direct links to external sites)

I don't think we really have the full answer yet but I'm VERY committed to figuring out how to not have that problem here.

Good to hear that you're aware of the challenges. It's very easy to make mistakes when designing systems like this. 

Do you also get input from Lyte and his crew on this? Trying to extract information about the quality of content from the site users while attempting to avoid pitfalls like endless feedback loops seems right up their alley.

I would really have to agree with Eleshakai here. The old forums were not that great with the way it was setup but I preferred it more because it made any conversation go from post 'A' to post 'Z' in a sense. This Reddit style forum makes it so you almost have to read the entire thread over again if you wish to follow the conversations.

Something else I do not really care for in many forums is the fact that there is essentially no quoting or it is does poorly. *Chan websites have a fairly useful way of quoting where you can specify the post number and if you hover over it, it shows the post. Even if multiple conversations are going on, you can follow them fairly easily so long as users use the function. The function works both ways as well, so if you are viewing the first post, you can hover over the link and it would display the reply and if you look at the reply, it would have a link you can hover over to read the first post. If it doesn't make much sense, you can look at a website like 4chan.org to get an idea of it.

Another function of several forums that I really like is the ability to, given you have read the thread before and there are new replies, 'jump' to the newest post in the thread. It makes it very simple to follow threads that are very popular or if you have a hard time remembering exactly what page you left off.

I do like the ability to hide and show posts, makes it slightly easier to remember what posts you have read and to just hide them when you are done reading them.

Last thing, I promise, I do not care for the upvote/downvote system because it generally just encourages users to follow a style of use like Reddit where members post merely for upvotes. The rating system, in my opinion, should not dictate a style of post that is prevalent on sites like Reddit. Instead, there should be a system that is more like 'This post helped me!' Everyone has a voice and the upvote/downvote system basically casts out unpopular ideas from a conversation that would otherwise benefit from it.

tl;dr Hard to follow specific conversations. Implement system like 4chan to easily quote other posts without creating really long pages. Make a 'jump to' button to easily navigate to the newest post. Good job on the 'hide/show' post function. Karma whoring may become as prevalent on here as it is on Reddit and essentially is just a really bad choice when you wish to promote deep conversations.


Weeeee! I wrote an essay for a website when I should be writing an essay for my class.
Wow, thanks  SSH Razor, this is very focused and useful feedback. Sorry to keep you from your essay-writing, but this I exactly the kind of info we're looking for.

Throw me into the same boat of 'being done' if the forums EVER go down in replacement of this style of 'community'. :-\ It's tiny, it's awkward to read on all counts, and on top of that you're pretty much going to obliterate the non-SR communities in one fell swoop.

I.E: Riot already treats the Dominion community as third class citizens. You don't keep your forum moderators in check (they move anything and everything they feel like to the Dominion sub-forum and never bother going there to moderate for us), any posts Dominion players make on the main LoL Reddit have to be mass-upvoted by the community just for it to stand a snowballs chance in hell of fighting against SR-auto-downvoters, and to top it off this Reddit style doesn't even have a Sub-Community for the alternate game modes.

If this becomes the replacement all non-SR threads are just going to vanish into the ether under a hailstorm of GD-style downvotes and moderator 'because I feel like it' deletions. (We already had one of your Reddit moderators delete a DominateDominion tournament thread a few weeks prior on false accusations.) There's no point in playing the game if I don't have a central community to talk to and bond with; that's easily more than half the fun. So it won't just be a 'done with the Reddit'. It will be a 'done with LoL'.

Seconded. I too am done with this if at the very least an option isn't put in for a Dominion forum, (and ARAM needs its own one as well). It's simply too confusing for people to have all the different game modes in the same forum. People will be replying to Dominion threads as if they're talking about SR, (this already happens when once in a blue moon a red posts in the Dom forums).

Stick with the forums, this format is awful and makes it ridiculously hard to track conversations.

As someone who is not involved with the development in any way:

Right at the top of each page, we have a drop-down that lets you sort by "Hot/Best" (as is the Reddit-esque style) as well as "New." It seems to me people can completely opt in to the more traditional chronological style of posting.

Is this accurate? Is this an easy enough fix for everyone?

It's not really accurate. For example, sorting this thread by "recent" at this moment gives the following time stamps (in hours aged)

1. 1h 
 1. now 
2. 3h 
3. 3h 
4. 4h
5. 4h
6. 4h
  1. 3h
7. 5h

It's sorted by main fork, not by detail. I think there should be an "unrolled" option. it lists everything without threading in order, and puts a simple "Parent" link to the thread it's responding to in the same line as the username.

For example, this would say:  
**BedderDanu** - now *Parent Link*

Have to agree here, as a wrenchman the traditional chronological order of threads aka the current forum is vital for me to see when a thread has been bumped or been posted in, the current changes would make my job very difficult to the point i would no longer enjoy it and would have to consider leaving the program to be quite honest
I think we'll have to figure out a special way to preserve the workflow for Wrenchmen if we decide to move forward with this model.
Are the players able to get similar tools to sort this mess out in a way it helps us?

I don't think a game's official forums should have a system that encourages hive-mind mentality. 

This is a large and passionate community. Sometimes controversial subjects come up (IE, female players / characters) and anybody who disagrees with popular opinion, even if it's well written and constructive, is going to get downvoted to shit even if they deserve to be heard.

And top rated comments are always going to be the cheap and easy winners. "THIS" and "Who fed xx cosplay" and "riot plz" while anything that people actually have to put effort into writing or reading is going to get lost in the noise.

I don't participate much in the LoL subreddit anymore for many of these reasons and I would be unlikely to use these anymore if it happens. 

That aside, this is just hard to navigate / read. I don't like the menu-style category list - I think having the major categories and sub-forums listed under is a better and classic layout for a forum. 

Forum taxonomy and style hasn't changed much in years because it works.  

http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/c/beta-feedback/XNg8bwhK-idea-pros-cons-style-suggestions-image-samples-included

^  Better style / ui feedback.

Thanks so much for your feedback. You got my vote. :) I'd also like to respond to a few of your concerns:

> This is a large and passionate community. Sometimes controversial subjects come up (IE, female players / characters) and anybody who disagrees with popular opinion, even if it's well written and constructive, is going to get downvoted to shit even if they deserve to be heard.

I'd ask that you wait to see if this plays out before you make a judgment call. We don't know if that will be the case, and so far I've seen many thoughtful, high quality contributions get upvotes, especially in this discussion, and lots more people have engaged with them than would have if they'd been in the middle of a long thread.

> And top rated comments are always going to be the cheap and easy winners.

That's a legitimate concern, but I think there are ways to address it. Pendragon outlined a few in his response: http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/c/beta-feedback/OI8QmnuW-if-this-reddit-style-goes-live-im-done?comment=000100010002

It's funny that you call this forum style a "sprawling mess" when that's exactly what every large thread in the normal forums turns into. It's easy to follow topics on reddit if you know how to use the system. Much easier, I've found, then on large traditional forums. It's also worth noting that this isn't a replacement for the forums; it's a supplement. If you don't like it, don't use it. Simple as that.

The things about a traditional forum is that while it can certainly be a mess, it's a mess in manageable and predictable pieces.

Pages break each thread up so you have a small and easily managed piece that you can divide your time with, You can easily read something in pieces because the thread tracks in an order that isn't going to change. Predictability makes a mess seem less messy.

Honestly, I don't see the LoL community as being as bad as you claim. There are a small portion of vocal trolls, but they're easily ignored... that being said, I do think that an option when viewing a thread to 'view only popular posts' would be helpful for some people to make it faster to read the information they specifically want out of a thread.

I think what we're trying to do is preserve the flow of conversation while improving the signal to noise ratio. We want the same back and forth to happen, we want both sides to be represented, (more where relevant), we just don't want you to have to wade through pages of nonsense to see it.

I actually think the linear display model lends to minority opinions being over-represented because there are so so many mechanisms are designed for the poster versus the reader.

Bumping is a great example - I can post a topic that is interesting or relevant to nobody but force tons of people to see it by repeatedly bumping. You could say that it's my right to do so, but in that case I'm not respecting the value of the reader's time by forcing them to read something that's not relevant or interesting to them.

In my view - people who are interested in the less popular discussions should be able to find them and have them, and people who aren't shouldn't have to see them.

And how, precisely, do you KNOW you aren't interested in that discussion if you never see it?

In a traditional forum - every topic, no matter how good, poor, trivial, or otherwise gets one chance for EVERYONE to see it. If someone else posts in it, it gets a second chance, and so on. 

In a reddit style, a post only gets one chance for people EXPLICITLY LOOKING FOR NEW POSTS, which since most of the discussion will be in the 'top' posts will be a minority of people. And after that one chance, it only gets further chances if enough people saw it in that first one for it to start trending for people to see it.

Most 'top' reddit posts get to the top because they get linked somewhere OUTSIDE of reddit. Another discussion community notices it and starts talking in it, spiking discussion. Very rarely do posts get noticed initially without some outside attention because there's just such a small chance of anyone ever seeing it.

This, to me, is a huge downside because it reduces the opportunities for people to do exactly what you described above: KNOW if they're interested in a less popular topic. It's not like your average person is going to be like 'okay I'm only interested in the popular topics regardless of what they actually are' - people have far more individual interests than that... by forcing people to effectively declare 'I am interested in new discussions' before they see new discussions, you're hamstringing your community.

Honestly, Pendragon, this is irrelevant. Whether you see everything or not doesn't matter, what matters is that every POST has an equal chance to be seen. On a typical forum every post is at the top in front of everyone for a brief second. ON reddit, new posts are NEVER in front of everyone.

New posts are ONLY seen by people who are directly linked to it from another website or people who are EXPLICITLY looking for something new. And that would be a very small number since most of the conversation is happening in the big threads and people don't want to miss out on those.

A typical forum allows you to see both new posts AND popular posts at the same time, meaning that a post being popular doesn't deny a new post it's 'one chance' to be seen. In Reddit you have to either choose do I want to see active or do I want to see new thus ensuring that new threads are seen by a far smaller audience and have a much lower chance of ever being noticed.
